Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Designing Programmable and Versatile Tags for Backscatter Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop an initial version of a Programmable and Versatile Backscattering Tag (PVBT) platform that will drive the research on backscatter-based systems of the future. The idea is to develop a modular, extensible and powerful hardware architecture for backscatter-based tags that is programmable at every layer. The PVBT hardware will be extensible in that the RF, analog and digital sections will be modular and exchangeable. In order to demonstrate the power of PVBT the PIs will build a small set of limited prototypes that will drive several core research directions. These will include (1) development and evaluation of protocols in the PHY/MAC layers providing higher speed and better interference management, (2) exploration of tag-to-tag communication and related networking protocols, (3) sensor networks utilizing backscatter communications.

Use of the PVBT will help researchers and manufacturers adopt PVBT-based evaluation in their workflow to develop new designs faster and at a lower cost, thereby helping RFIDs make more inroads in the marketplace. On the educational front, the PIs will initiate development of an online course on backscatter-based systems. The PVBT will also act as a platform for (i) summer projects of local high school students via several programs at SBU, (ii) research and inquiry-based courses in the WISE (Women In Science & Engineering) Program at SBU, (iii) senior projects of engineering undergraduates, and (iv) course/thesis projects for graduate students at SBU.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has developed a prototype tag architecture that communicates with other similar tags via backscattering an external RF signal. This form of "passive" mode of communication is attractive as it does not require active, power hungry radio transceiver on-board. The small amount of power needed to power the circuits and on-board intelligence can come from harvested power from the external RF signal itself. Such tags can be serve as drivers of  future Internet of Things as they could be battery-less and still able to communicate over long distances using multihop relaying via other tags in the neighborhood.

The project developed a flexible and modular architecture of such tags so that different components of the tag can be changed and experimented with. This can form the basis of a future research testbed driving research on multihop tag-to-tag networking. PCB-based prototypes have been built for an example implementation of different sections of the tag, including antenna, receive section, backscatter modulator and microcontroller. Tag to tag communication performance using an external RF exciter has been studied. Two tags are able to communicate virually error free over 3m with only minimal exciter power available. This performance is better or competitive with similar work reported in recent literature but with a simpler and modular architecture.
